newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Ashton sees output of 38 mln carats.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Ashton sees output of 38 mln carats.

text.p: Ashton Mining Ltd said on Thursday that it expects Argyle diamond production to total about 38 million carats in full year 1996.
It also said it sees solid progress in direct marketing of diamonds and sustained growth in international retail diamond jewellery sales.
Diamond production in the half-year to June 30 from Argyle totaled 21.3 million carats, up from 19 million carats in the corresponding period a year earlier, the company said.
The company also forecast that strong growth would continue in Indian polished diamond exports.

Ashton said a project development decision was due in October at its Merlin project, where results of diamond parcel valuations from the first two bulk samples were US$76 and $60 per carat, the company said.
A go-ahead for the project in October would allow production to begin by late 1997, the company said.
First-half diamond sales from Argyle totaled 22.4 million carats, up from 12.1 million in the same period a year ago, Ashton said.
The increase reflects increased sales through Argyle's European Sales Office (ESO) and the Central Selling Organisation (CSO), the company said.
As of June 30, Argyle is direct-marketing the rough diamonds it produces through the ESO in Antwerp after opting out of the CSO, following expiry of sales contracts with the CSO.
Diamond sales for the short period since the commencement of the new arrangement are in line with forecasts, Ashton said.
In India, discussions with established customers are continuing to ensure Argyle's marketing approach operates smoothly, Ashton said.
India is the largest market for Argyle rough diamonds. About 95 percent of Argyle's production is cut and polished in India.
Ashton earlier reported a net profit of A$12.44 million for the latest half-year, up from A$9.65 million in the corresponding period a year ago.
